elements.text: [Part One]
Strong wind blowing. The Tardis materialises. Scanner turned on.
Well, just look at that.
It's beautiful.
Isn't it? Wide open ice fields stretching out for hundreds of miles.
What's the name of this planet?
Ah. I'm afraid it's Earth again, actually, Nyssa. A place called Alaska.
Oh, is that near where we left Tegan?
Oh, no, no. We're a long way from Heathrow. Alaska is the stepping stone between America and Asia, two of Earth's largest continents.
Then where are the people? Doctor, I can't see any dwellings.

We're probably too far north. It's not the most hospitable of environments, but rich in natural resources like oil. While natives have lived off the land for thousands of years, Tegan's people have really only been interested in Alaska for commercial or strategic
Beeping.
Interesting.
What is?
Energy reading of some kind. The kind the Tardis can't recognise but seems receptive to. Why should we start picking up some random emission like
Doctor, that looks like smoke rising up from there.

Too much to come from a cosy fire up the chimney. If only the panning controls were working, we could look down and see what's happening. And if only the audio circuits were more reliable, perhaps we could hear something of what's going on.
Burble noise.
Doctor!
The Tardis dematerialises.
Close.
What was it?
A plane. Not the kind you'd find Tegan stewardessing on. Some kind of light aircraft. Privately chartered, I'd imagine. The pilot clearly wasn't looking where he was going.
I don't suppose he was expecting a large blue box to be hovering in mid-air over Alaska.
Yes, well. Still, if we didn't expect the unexpected, whatever would become of us.
Banging noises.
You've been telling me that panelling would be here tomorrow for three weeks now.
Tomorrow, okay? Definitely tomorrow. You've got my word on that, okay?
Your word as a gentleman or an incompetent? I'm not inclined to believe either any more. Go on, get out of it. God knows it would be quicker to go back to England and get it myself. Oh God, if only.
Door opens.
Ah, Mister Brett. Good afternoon.
Monica.
Remind me. We are in the wilds of the North, aren't we, rather than the Wild West? Because I've never encountered so many cowboys.
Perhaps we should discuss this somewhere a little more private.
I mean, can even you really be so rich as to throw away your cash on idiots like these?
Monica, you know the problems we've been having getting hold of our more specialist materials. Persist in terrifying our suppliers like that and they'll never deliver anything.
We'd be hard pressed to notice the difference. I mean, three weeks, for God's sake? This job's taken three years of my life from me, knocked another twenty off in stress, and still the delays go on.

Monica, I appreciate you're a little exasperated with conditions here, but since we're in the Land of the Midnight Sun, perhaps you could let a little of it filter through to brighten your disposition, hmm? Why you even insist on remaining baffles me. Your plans have been worked out quite accurately. Gaborik is perfectly capable of chivvying the work along in your absence. You've not had a proper break for six months now. Are all interior designers so strict with themselves?
All right, all right. Sorry. Strop over. It's just, I don't know, this place, there's something about it.
The area holds a particular charm, I agree.
It's not that. I can't wait to get back to grass stains, hay fever and gnat bites, believe me.
Well, Monica, four more months and the entire installation will be more or less complete. The work mustn't suffer. I keep telling you, take a break now and return for the final stages.
Take a break and do what? I've abandoned all pretence at having anything approaching a life for so long now. I can't start picking up the pieces back home until this project is over.
Have it your own way. In the meantime, I'll get Gaborik to check those supply dates. We're so close now. So close.
The Tardis materialises. Burbling beeps.
Curiouser and curiouser.
We've landed.
Yes. Same area, different time.
1994. Doctor, your energy reading is still registering.
Let me see. Hmm.
We've moved forward about thirty years.
Almost as if the Tardis was following a scent. These readings suggest the emissions decayed to trace levels soon after we left.
But are increasing quite significantly now.
Yes, well, but what kind of energy is it, I wonder, hmm? Hard to tell if it really is a power source that the Tardis can't identify, or if
The Tardis simply isn't functioning properly.

It's an outside chance, I suppose. Speaking about outside, you'd better go and get yourself a warm coat. Oh, and pick up the hand-held tracker from the tool box, could you? We'll need it to trace the source of the emissions.
Is that necessary?
It's best to check. Besides, aren't you at all curious?
Heavy footsteps.
Gaborik, wait up.
Mister Brett wants me to check delivery dates for the furs before
he goes.
You've been speaking to Johnny Oldman up at Bethel, haven't you, filling his head with garbage.
Something is the matter?
You know damn well there is. He'd agreed to the sale. Now he's not letting us access his jetty to take away the earth he's already sold us.
Perhaps he has changed his mind.
Perhaps you changed it for him.
He talked to me, sure, but why would I tell him stories? Brett's money feeds my family just as it does you.

Precisely. And when this place is finished, that money dries up, doesn't it, huh? Brett will discard you along with everyone else. Ever since he made you his personal assistant, you've been stirring things up behind his back.
You do not understand, Tulung, because you see the world with one Koyukon eye and one that is American. Your kind will never understand my people.
You are acting for yourself in this, not our people.
Johnny Oldman will act as he will. I have not turned him against you.

Brett knows about the bad feeling you tried to spread in the Koyukon about this house. It amuses him, you understand that? He doesn't really care. It's a hindrance, sure, but he knows he'll win in the end. It amuses him to think that you, the Koyukon, could ever stand in his way.
If that is true, and as your job here is to run between him and my people, finding ways to make everyone happy, at whose expense is he really gaining his anusement?
Heavy footsteps recede.
Walking on snow.
You know, it was Peter the Great that believed there was a part of America beyond Siberia.
These place names don't mean anything to me, Doctor.
So he sent explorers here. It took them more or less eight years to reach Alaska, and the Captain would only allow his crew ten hours ashore before turning back.
The readings are increasing a fraction. I think we're heading the right way.
And you know what they found in those ten hours? A blue jay, a bird they knew lived only in America. Proof positive that Peter the Great was right.
Is that a jay there?
No, that looks like a raven.
Walking further on.
Of course, the raven is the creator god in the beliefs of the Koyukon people, the descendants of the original settlers who came here more than twelve thousand years ago.
Doctor, shush. What's that?
What's what?
I heard something, like there's something out here, watching us.
Probably a wayward blue jay, wondering why his ears were burning. Come on.
Further on.
Well, look at that. I bet that's not been built by the locals.
It's a remarkable building.
And not entirely finished yet, if that scaffolding's anything to go by. But impressive nonetheless. I wonder if they'd give us a guided tour?
Perhaps you can ask. The tracker's indicating we head towards it.
Why am I not entirely surprised at that.
Will we get there by nightfall, do you think?
Perhaps. You know, in summer here the sun never sets. Of course, Alaska is so named from the Aleutian word Alyeska, meaning The Great Land.
Johnny Oldman can be talked around, Brett. Give me time with him. Brett?

There was a time when I didn't mind the endless wrestling with the Koyukon. I almost welcomed the setbacks. Each was something to be overcome, something to feel good about, each another victory, another step closer.
But now you worry you're too close.
You know me better than anyone, don't you, little Tulung. Always so very dependable. Oh, I'm tired. It's taken so much to make this place happen.
You worry what's going to happen to you when it's over.
And what will become of you, little Tulung?
My work here will be done, but I still belong. I'll always have my place here with the Koyukon.

Oh, well said, but not really all that convincing. Look at you standing there. Even know you feel the mixed blood that flows through your veins pulling you this way and that. No peace, only conflict. But you don't belong to the Koyukon. You don't even belong to the white man. You belong to me. You feel that deep down, don't you, little Tulung, hmm?
I do wish you had a brighter torch.
Hmm. Batteries must be wearing down a little. Well, at least it's doubtful we'll step in anything unpleasant out here.
Sound of something heavy walking on snow.
It's there again. That sound.
Yes. Got to keep moving. This track must lead direct to that building, and if it stays clear, then
Roar!
Doctor!
Animal roars and birds screeching.
Nyssa, get behind me.
It's so massive! Is it native to Alaska?
I doubt it's even native to Earth.
Can you understand us?
Roar! Screeches.
We mean you no harm.
I'm not sure it can say the same.
Doctor, that must be another one behind us. It's been tracking us!
Or hunting us. We're trapped.
Can we outrun them, do you think?
We'll have to take that chance. I'll flash the torch at it, try to keep its attention. Circle behind it but keep well clear. Make for the building.
But what about you?
If I'm not right behind you, see if you can get help. Now quickly!
Running on snow.
Now, let's try and shed a little light on you, shall we? You and your friend here.
Torch clicking on and off. Snarling.
Hmm, what big teeth you have. Perhaps it's not such a shame the torch isn't stronger.
Doctor! Doctor, it's after me!
While its friend here focuses on me. If I can just overtake on the inside. Come on, Nyssa, quickly, run!
Monica is humming when a door opens.
What? Oh, hello, Tulung. Don't tread on that paint, it costs a fortune. Everything okay?
Er, yeah. Yeah, thank you, Miss Lewis.
You don't seem entirely sure.
It's Brett.
Oh, isn't it always?
He seems more distant than ever.

Does he? Seems pretty much his usual charming self, knowing what's best for everyone. Poor little rich boy slumming it with us commoners just to get what he wants. God knows what he'll be like when we're finished up here and he has to face up to reality by himself. What's bothering you?
Ah, it's probably nothing. I mean, he's just been, it's like something's changed in him. He's even harder, darker somehow.
Well, I don't recall him ever being that big a barrel of laughs, do you?
Perhaps it's me. I take so much from him in the general run of things anyway that I barely notice the aggression, and then he goes and ups it all a notch and I have to adjust. I'll get used to it.
You don't have to get used to it. There's still a doorway in the front of this place, you know. I'm an expert. Trust me. They're there to be walked through.
No, not yet.
Seems we're all stuck here together. Just can't bear to leave the place, can we.
Thumping on distant door.
Hell, what's that?
That door you were just talking about, I think. I'll go see what's up. Although you said you're the expert. Perhaps you should go.
Mind the paint tins on your way out, Tulung.
Sorry.
And don't let whoever it is knock that door down. It'll take weeks to get a new one delivered.
Knocking on door, footsteps. Door opened.
What is this? What do you want?
To come in. Thank you!
Who are you? What do you want?
Door closed.
We're visitors. So sorry to drop by unannounced.
We were attacked. Something out there.
Attacked?
Yes.
What something? What was it?
There's no time to explain now. We need flashlights. It may well be coming this way.
Your clothes.
Quite striking, aren't they? Now, please, you must listen. Something very large and aggressive was lurking out there on the track. I
don't suppose you know anything about it?
Footsteps.
Strangers.
Only until we're introduced. I'm the Doctor, this is my friend Nyssa, and as I was saying to your friend here, Mister er
You must leave here. This is private property.
You can't just throw us out to face that thing!
You have no business here.
You have no business yourself, Gaborik, throwing out these people into the night. It is for Mister Brett to decide, is it not?
Oh, absolutely. Good old Mister Brett.
Fetch him, Gaborik. I'll watch them.
Footsteps recede.
Thank you.
Yes, thank you, Mister er
My name is Tulung. Are you lost?
Well, I wouldn't say that, exactly.
We know this is Alaska.
Well, welcome to Kyusk.

I'm sure Mister Brett will be absolutely delighted to see us, but we may find some rather less well-mannered guests dropping by for dinner if whatever's out there is still following us. We need to er. What a terribly lavish reception area. Not very homely though, is it. More like a museum foyer than an entrance hall. No coat stand.
Doctor.
Nyssa, what's wrong?
I'm not sure. My head, it's tingling.
Please, sit down here. You've been running?
Yes.
Perhaps the exertion and the change of temperature.
Well, Nyssa?
I'm fine, really. Please, Doctor, we must find out what that thing was.
Yes, you're quite right. So, Mister Tulung, this is an impressive building. Do you have equally impressive floodlights for the grounds?
I'll switch them on.
Splendid. If one of those creatures has followed us, at least we should be able to see what we're up against.
Be careful, Doctor. The readings are clearer here. Look.
Interesting. Whatever it is, we must be right on top of it. Ah, lead on, Mister Tulung.
Walking on snow.
No, not a sign. Perhaps they don't like the light.
Perhaps. And you've seen nothing like these animals before?
No, I don't believe I have.
I shall leave the lights on.
Good idea. In the morning we can hunt for tracks.
In the morning? You mean to stay here?
Ah. I might prevail upon the good nature of our host, yes.
I see.
Our transport isn't er, always that reliable, and given our recent experience out there.
Door opens, footsteps, door closes.
Well?
Nothing.
I can't say I'm not relieved.
How are you feeling?
Better, thank you.
Footsteps.
Mister Brett invites you to the drawing room.
How very pleasant of him.
Take them there, Tulung. I have business to attend to.
Footsteps recede.
I don't think your friend likes us much.
Gaborik doesn't like anyone, and few care for him in return. He holds little respect for the ways of our people, unless it suits him. But come, we'll be more comfortable in the drawing room.
Fire crackling.
Well, this is cosy. Thank you, Tulung. It's a large house. Do you stay here too?
Yes, sometimes. There are many guest rooms in the annex here, but I have lodgings at Evansville a few miles away. I prefer it there.
This room, the furnishings, the whole style of it is so different to the hall downstairs. Still, it doesn't feel much like a home.
It was never intended to be. Home is where the heart is. There's no heart in this place, only shadows. Brett had it built for nothing.
He likes the area?
It's made him a rich man. He's a millionaire a dozen times over now, thanks to Alaskan oil, but yeah, yeah, the area has a special significance.
The site itself, there's something unusual about it?
His father died not far from here, same place my own dad died.
I'm so sorry.
I take it that's Brett senior hanging up above the mantelpiece there.

That's right. This place is far more than just somewhere to stay. It's a monument, a kind of mausoleum if you like, a tribute to Brett's father and his all-consuming passion for the land and its secrets.
He was an archaeologist?

It was his hobby. He used to joke that he'd dig up Alaska any way he could, but for my father. He was a professional. These lands are rich in fossils buried deep in the permafrost. My father was from Colorado, but he spent much of his life out here. It wasn't easy, especially after he married a Koyukon. We moved about all over the state when I was a kid, always chasing more funding, another dig.
And that's how you and Mister Brett first met?

Yeah. And how my father died. What Brett's father lacked in knowledge and ability, he made up for in cash. He funded the digs, but he made damn sure everyone knew who was calling the shots. That's one trait he passed on to his son.
Door opens and closes.
An admirable trait, in my view. Everyone knows so clearly where they stand, don't they, little Tulung.
How do you do? I'm the Doctor.
Shaun Brett. And you, my dear?
My name is Nyssa. Thank you for your hospitality.
It's a most delightful pleasure for me to have company. This is such a solitary place. How came you to be here in Koyukuk? You're dressed for a
game of cricket, I see.
Yes, sadly called off. Due to snow, apparently.
My assistant says you were pursued out there.
Something like that. Tell me, do you know this area well?
I do.
He's hoarding great chunks of it downstairs.
I am cherishing this area, shall we say.
So you'd notice anything unusual about it?
Would you care to be shown around downstairs, Doctor, to experience a little of the landscape?
I'm sorry?
Do join me, please. And you, Miss Nyssa.
Nyssa?
My head, neck. I'm sorry, I think I'll stay here.
I'll wait with you.
Do so, little Tulung. We'll not be long.
(sotto) Doctor, what about the tracker, the energy readings?
(sotto) That's exactly why I think I should take a look around. (normal) Lead on, Mister Brett.
Footsteps recede, door opens.
Little Tulung.
He seems a very cold man.
My mother used to say he carries the chill of the lands with him. It's buried in him, like my father's buried out there.
Tulung, I know what it is to lose a father, to lose so much more than that. What happened?
There's not a lot to tell. I was ten, Brett was twelve. It was 1964.
Thirty years ago. I'm sorry. Please, go on.

(sighs) The dig was only a couple of miles from here. They'd found something. My father was excited, terribly excited. But there was a cave-in, something went wrong, something Brett's father never ever talked about, not to anyone. But he was the only one who walked away from that dig alive.
And this is the Stone room.
Everything's solid rock.
Naturally. Floor, walls, ceiling, furniture.
And all local materials?
The raw stuff of the area. What better to convey my father's admiration for the lands he embraced so warmly.
And what better than these lanterns to illuminate it all by. Terribly atmospheric.
Reverent, Doctor.
I'm sorry. Of course. So, a Timber room, an Earth room.
I have a room in progress that will be fashioned purely from ice garnered from the Arctic shores.
Chilly.
All aspects of the lands must be reflected, Doctor, for this to be a truly fitting monument. I use wholly natural resources or nothing at all.
Hmm. And the Koyukon don't mind you carving up great chunks of their land?
There Tulung is of use to me. He helps the Koyukon see I am respectful to their lands.
And Gaborik?
Further local colour. He is a somewhat political appointment, I must
confess.
Useful in convincing the Koyukon that you can all work together.
Particularly when I'm paying them all so well for their contributions.
Ah, the age-old conflict. Tradition and progress.
Here, I unite them. Doctor, under one roof. The twin watchwords of my father. He uncovered the past and made it his own.
But was it his to take?
And now, if you'd follow me, I shall show you my greatest achievement.
My Sea room.
Shame it's so cold. You'd always have somewhere to lay your beach towel.
Remarkable, isn't it? The house is actually build into the rock face. It forms the far wall there.
And is the rest of the landscape so genuine?
Five hundred thousand gallons of Arctic seawater and an actual stretch of coastline, all transplanted and reconstructed.
You even have your own virtual tides.
Keyed to the movement of our holographic moon. There's even sea life here. Seals, walruses.
Oh, I'm sure they appreciate it all far more than the real thing. Perhaps that's why we can't see any of them today.
You don't approve, Doctor.
Oh, it's an extraordinary achievement, absolutely. It's only the context I question.
I can show you someone who would argue that's precisely the point. It's her vision and skill that has brought my dreams to fruition. Perhaps you'd like to meet her?
Doctor, may I present Monica Lewis, a most gifted interior designer. Monica, this is my guest for the evening, Doctor
How do you do?
I do fine, thank you, Doctor. A guest, eh? Can't remember when one of those last came to call.
I imagine you're a little cut off here.
Mind the paint.
It's a little dangerous piled up there, isn't it?
Is your friend from Health and Safety, Mister Brett?
The Doctor and his friend upstairs are travellers who ran into trouble.
We so often do. You're the architect of all this, I take it, Miss Lewis.
Amongst other things.
From England?
Right. You too?
Er, not exactly. You know, I'd say your larder here could use a good clean out, Mister Brett.
(laughs) Not at all, Doctor. This is my Bone room.
Isn't that taking your interest in natural materials a little far?
This house simply won't be complete without it.
Gruesome, isn't it? Gives me nightmares, to be honest. Still, it's a great opportunity. So little provokes a reaction these days.
And so little is sacred.
Your mentioning the larder has reminded me. It's dinner time, Doctor.
I seem to have lost my appetite.
Oh, come, come, Doctor. I insist you dine with me. You and your friend. You too, of course, Monica. We'll spend a pleasant while together.
All right, why not?
We'll say eight thirty.
That was very nice, Gaborik. Thank you.
It certainly looked delicious. I'm sorry I wasn't very hungry.
Yes, thank you, Gaborik. Workmanlike as ever.
The flesh of the animal was wrong. The taste is not right.
Really?
Glad I'm vegetarian, then. I wouldn't know sea otter from sushi. Great salad though, Gaborik.
It is what they are doing to the sea to get oil that spoils the taste.
Is it?
That's your parochial paranoia speaking again, Gaborik. I shan't allow you to sit at table again if you insist on being so discourteous to the traditions of my Western guests.
Mister Brett.
Please, you shouldn't. There's really no need to
You all right, Nyssa?
I think so.

What do you think, Monica? Will these choice table-leavings benefit our Bone room? Oh, it will be a magnificent sight when finished. A shining white chamber, a cage of vertebrae and skulls, a testament to the ancient animal dead.
(nauseous) Please.
So squeamish, my dear?
She's not been well since we got here. Nyssa, look at me. Hmm, you may have a slight temperature.
I could use a little walkabout after all that food. Would you like to come along, Nyssa?
Thank you, I, I think I might.
Probably just what you need.
Footsteps recede.
Now, where were we?
You were trying to provoke Gaborik and myself into arguing yet again against your ghoulish vision. The Koyukon
It's so sweet when you try and empathise with Gaborik's views.
Something's stirring. Maybe this walk wasn't such a good idea. Come on, let's get some sea air. Well, the next best thing. Might cool this fever down a little.
Doors to the Sea room hiss open.
The sea. Something from the sea.
You're not well, are you? Tell you what, you just rest here. I'll go and tell your friend. He's a doctor.
Footsteps on sand or snow, door closes. Sound of waves.
Something from the sea.
You just don't get it, Brett. Animals need to be treated with respect, or they would not give themselves to the hunter.
Such tedious superstition.
It's not superstition! It's something that's evolved over thousands of years. The culture, the land, the animals, they can't be separated and packaged up the way you're doing.
Listen to your choice of words. Does that sound like a Koyukon to
you, Gaborik?
I wouldn't really
You're really trying too hard, little Tulung.
I won't let you
I really to think
Door opens.
Doctor! I think you'd better take a look
Whumph noise.
What the hell was that?
It came from below us.
That's the Stone room. Quickly.
The whole wall's cracked open. How can that have happened? It's impossible.
Well, it evidently has, my dear Monica.
I worked on this myself.
Am I to blame your handiwork?
I wouldn't, if I were you. We'll have to re-render the entire wall. Damn. How deep is it?
Wait, wait, wait. Let me take a look.
What?
Yes, something's caused that rock to break open.
Hold on. I, I can see something inside this split.
Careful. Yes, you're right. Where's Nyssa?
Oh, she wasn't up to walking far. I left her resting in the Sea room.
I'd better fetch her. Touch nothing, any of you, until we're back. Nothing.
Footsteps recede.
Cheek of the man.
We'd better get a light in here. There's definitely something in the rock.
Let me see. Gaborik, fetch a stronger light, man.
The Doctor said we should leave it.
It is bad, I sense it.
Looks to be some kind of fossil.
Sea room doors hiss but do not open.
Nyssa? Nyssa, are you all right? The door seems to be stuck.
From the sea. It's so dark in here, so cold.
[OC]: Nyssa! Nyssa, if you can hear me, come to the door..
Doctor, they're coming for me!
[OC]: What's happening, Nyssa?
Creatures, born and reborn. They're all around me. They want to kill, want to kill us all!
[OC]: Nyssa!
Roar!

parts.searchable_dialogue:
DOCTOR: Well, just look at that.
NYSSA: It's beautiful.
DOCTOR: Isn't it? Wide open ice fields stretching out for hundreds of miles.
NYSSA: What's the name of this planet?
DOCTOR: Ah. I'm afraid it's Earth again, actually, Nyssa. A place called Alaska.
NYSSA: Oh, is that near where we left Tegan?
DOCTOR: Oh, no, no. We're a long way from Heathrow. Alaska is the stepping stone between America and Asia, two of Earth's largest continents.
NYSSA: Then where are the people? Doctor, I can't see any dwellings.
DOCTOR: We're probably too far north. It's not the most hospitable of environments, but rich in natural resources like oil. While natives have lived off the land for thousands of years, Tegan's people have really only been interested in Alaska for commercial or strategic
DOCTOR: Interesting.
NYSSA: What is?
DOCTOR: Energy reading of some kind. The kind the Tardis can't recognise but seems receptive to. Why should we start picking up some random emission like
NYSSA: Doctor, that looks like smoke rising up from there.
DOCTOR: Too much to come from a cosy fire up the chimney. If only the panning controls were working, we could look down and see what's happening. And if only the audio circuits were more reliable, perhaps we could hear something of what's going on.
NYSSA: Doctor!
DOCTOR: Close.
NYSSA: What was it?
DOCTOR: A plane. Not the kind you'd find Tegan stewardessing on. Some kind of light aircraft. Privately chartered, I'd imagine. The pilot clearly wasn't looking where he was going.
NYSSA: I don't suppose he was expecting a large blue box to be hovering in mid-air over Alaska.
DOCTOR: Yes, well. Still, if we didn't expect the unexpected, whatever would become of us.
MONICA: You've been telling me that panelling would be here tomorrow for three weeks now.
SUPPLIER: Tomorrow, okay? Definitely tomorrow. You've got my word on that, okay?
MONICA: Your word as a gentleman or an incompetent? I'm not inclined to believe either any more. Go on, get out of it. God knows it would be quicker to go back to England and get it myself. Oh God, if only.
MONICA: Ah, Mister Brett. Good afternoon.
BRETT: Monica.
MONICA: Remind me. We are in the wilds of the North, aren't we, rather than the Wild West? Because I've never encountered so many cowboys.
BRETT: Perhaps we should discuss this somewhere a little more private.
MONICA: I mean, can even you really be so rich as to throw away your cash on idiots like these?
BRETT: Monica, you know the problems we've been having getting hold of our more specialist materials. Persist in terrifying our suppliers like that and they'll never deliver anything.
MONICA: We'd be hard pressed to notice the difference. I mean, three weeks, for God's sake? This job's taken three years of my life from me, knocked another twenty off in stress, and still the delays go on.
BRETT: Monica, I appreciate you're a little exasperated with conditions here, but since we're in the Land of the Midnight Sun, perhaps you could let a little of it filter through to brighten your disposition, hmm? Why you even insist on remaining baffles me. Your plans have been worked out quite accurately. Gaborik is perfectly capable of chivvying the work along in your absence. You've not had a proper break for six months now. Are all interior designers so strict with themselves?
MONICA: All right, all right. Sorry. Strop over. It's just, I don't know, this place, there's something about it.
BRETT: The area holds a particular charm, I agree.
MONICA: It's not that. I can't wait to get back to grass stains, hay fever and gnat bites, believe me.
BRETT: Well, Monica, four more months and the entire installation will be more or less complete. The work mustn't suffer. I keep telling you, take a break now and return for the final stages.
MONICA: Take a break and do what? I've abandoned all pretence at having anything approaching a life for so long now. I can't start picking up the pieces back home until this project is over.
BRETT: Have it your own way. In the meantime, I'll get Gaborik to check those supply dates. We're so close now. So close.
DOCTOR: Curiouser and curiouser.
NYSSA: We've landed.
DOCTOR: Yes. Same area, different time.
NYSSA: 1994. Doctor, your energy reading is still registering.
DOCTOR: Let me see. Hmm.
NYSSA: We've moved forward about thirty years.
DOCTOR: Almost as if the Tardis was following a scent. These readings suggest the emissions decayed to trace levels soon after we left.
NYSSA: But are increasing quite significantly now.
DOCTOR: Yes, well, but what kind of energy is it, I wonder, hmm? Hard to tell if it really is a power source that the Tardis can't identify, or if
NYSSA: The Tardis simply isn't functioning properly.
DOCTOR: It's an outside chance, I suppose. Speaking about outside, you'd better go and get yourself a warm coat. Oh, and pick up the hand-held tracker from the tool box, could you? We'll need it to trace the source of the emissions.
NYSSA: Is that necessary?
DOCTOR: It's best to check. Besides, aren't you at all curious?
TULUNG: Gaborik, wait up.
GABORIK: Mister Brett wants me to check delivery dates for the furs before
GABORIK: he goes.
TULUNG: You've been speaking to Johnny Oldman up at Bethel, haven't you, filling his head with garbage.
GABORIK: Something is the matter?
TULUNG: You know damn well there is. He'd agreed to the sale. Now he's not letting us access his jetty to take away the earth he's already sold us.
GABORIK: Perhaps he has changed his mind.
TULUNG: Perhaps you changed it for him.
GABORIK: He talked to me, sure, but why would I tell him stories? Brett's money feeds my family just as it does you.
TULUNG: Precisely. And when this place is finished, that money dries up, doesn't it, huh? Brett will discard you along with everyone else. Ever since he made you his personal assistant, you've been stirring things up behind his back.
GABORIK: You do not understand, Tulung, because you see the world with one Koyukon eye and one that is American. Your kind will never understand my people.
TULUNG: You are acting for yourself in this, not our people.
GABORIK: Johnny Oldman will act as he will. I have not turned him against you.
TULUNG: Brett knows about the bad feeling you tried to spread in the Koyukon about this house. It amuses him, you understand that? He doesn't really care. It's a hindrance, sure, but he knows he'll win in the end. It amuses him to think that you, the Koyukon, could ever stand in his way.
GABORIK: If that is true, and as your job here is to run between him and my people, finding ways to make everyone happy, at whose expense is he really gaining his anusement?
DOCTOR: You know, it was Peter the Great that believed there was a part of America beyond Siberia.
NYSSA: These place names don't mean anything to me, Doctor.
DOCTOR: So he sent explorers here. It took them more or less eight years to reach Alaska, and the Captain would only allow his crew ten hours ashore before turning back.
NYSSA: The readings are increasing a fraction. I think we're heading the right way.
DOCTOR: And you know what they found in those ten hours? A blue jay, a bird they knew lived only in America. Proof positive that Peter the Great was right.
NYSSA: Is that a jay there?
DOCTOR: No, that looks like a raven.
DOCTOR: Of course, the raven is the creator god in the beliefs of the Koyukon people, the descendants of the original settlers who came here more than twelve thousand years ago.
NYSSA: Doctor, shush. What's that?
DOCTOR: What's what?
NYSSA: I heard something, like there's something out here, watching us.
DOCTOR: Probably a wayward blue jay, wondering why his ears were burning. Come on.
DOCTOR: Well, look at that. I bet that's not been built by the locals.
NYSSA: It's a remarkable building.
DOCTOR: And not entirely finished yet, if that scaffolding's anything to go by. But impressive nonetheless. I wonder if they'd give us a guided tour?
NYSSA: Perhaps you can ask. The tracker's indicating we head towards it.
DOCTOR: Why am I not entirely surprised at that.
NYSSA: Will we get there by nightfall, do you think?
DOCTOR: Perhaps. You know, in summer here the sun never sets. Of course, Alaska is so named from the Aleutian word Alyeska, meaning The Great Land.
TULUNG: Johnny Oldman can be talked around, Brett. Give me time with him. Brett?
BRETT: There was a time when I didn't mind the endless wrestling with the Koyukon. I almost welcomed the setbacks. Each was something to be overcome, something to feel good about, each another victory, another step closer.
TULUNG: But now you worry you're too close.
BRETT: You know me better than anyone, don't you, little Tulung. Always so very dependable. Oh, I'm tired. It's taken so much to make this place happen.
TULUNG: You worry what's going to happen to you when it's over.
BRETT: And what will become of you, little Tulung?
TULUNG: My work here will be done, but I still belong. I'll always have my place here with the Koyukon.
BRETT: Oh, well said, but not really all that convincing. Look at you standing there. Even know you feel the mixed blood that flows through your veins pulling you this way and that. No peace, only conflict. But you don't belong to the Koyukon. You don't even belong to the white man. You belong to me. You feel that deep down, don't you, little Tulung, hmm?
NYSSA: I do wish you had a brighter torch.
DOCTOR: Hmm. Batteries must be wearing down a little. Well, at least it's doubtful we'll step in anything unpleasant out here.
NYSSA: It's there again. That sound.
DOCTOR: Yes. Got to keep moving. This track must lead direct to that building, and if it stays clear, then
NYSSA: Doctor!
DOCTOR: Nyssa, get behind me.
NYSSA: It's so massive! Is it native to Alaska?
DOCTOR: I doubt it's even native to Earth.
NYSSA: Can you understand us?
NYSSA: We mean you no harm.
DOCTOR: I'm not sure it can say the same.
NYSSA: Doctor, that must be another one behind us. It's been tracking us!
DOCTOR: Or hunting us. We're trapped.
NYSSA: Can we outrun them, do you think?
DOCTOR: We'll have to take that chance. I'll flash the torch at it, try to keep its attention. Circle behind it but keep well clear. Make for the building.
NYSSA: But what about you?
DOCTOR: If I'm not right behind you, see if you can get help. Now quickly!
DOCTOR: Now, let's try and shed a little light on you, shall we? You and your friend here.
DOCTOR: Hmm, what big teeth you have. Perhaps it's not such a shame the torch isn't stronger.
NYSSA: Doctor! Doctor, it's after me!
DOCTOR: While its friend here focuses on me. If I can just overtake on the inside. Come on, Nyssa, quickly, run!
MONICA: What? Oh, hello, Tulung. Don't tread on that paint, it costs a fortune. Everything okay?
TULUNG: Er, yeah. Yeah, thank you, Miss Lewis.
MONICA: You don't seem entirely sure.
TULUNG: It's Brett.
MONICA: Oh, isn't it always?
TULUNG: He seems more distant than ever.
MONICA: Does he? Seems pretty much his usual charming self, knowing what's best for everyone. Poor little rich boy slumming it with us commoners just to get what he wants. God knows what he'll be like when we're finished up here and he has to face up to reality by himself. What's bothering you?
TULUNG: Ah, it's probably nothing. I mean, he's just been, it's like something's changed in him. He's even harder, darker somehow.
MONICA: Well, I don't recall him ever being that big a barrel of laughs, do you?
TULUNG: Perhaps it's me. I take so much from him in the general run of things anyway that I barely notice the aggression, and then he goes and ups it all a notch and I have to adjust. I'll get used to it.
MONICA: You don't have to get used to it. There's still a doorway in the front of this place, you know. I'm an expert. Trust me. They're there to be walked through.
TULUNG: No, not yet.
MONICA: Seems we're all stuck here together. Just can't bear to leave the place, can we.
MONICA: Hell, what's that?
TULUNG: That door you were just talking about, I think. I'll go see what's up. Although you said you're the expert. Perhaps you should go.
MONICA: Mind the paint tins on your way out, Tulung.
TULUNG: Sorry.
MONICA: And don't let whoever it is knock that door down. It'll take weeks to get a new one delivered.
GABORIK: What is this? What do you want?
DOCTOR: To come in. Thank you!
GABORIK: Who are you? What do you want?
DOCTOR: We're visitors. So sorry to drop by unannounced.
NYSSA: We were attacked. Something out there.
GABORIK: Attacked?
DOCTOR: Yes.
GABORIK: What something? What was it?
DOCTOR: There's no time to explain now. We need flashlights. It may well be coming this way.
GABORIK: Your clothes.
DOCTOR: Quite striking, aren't they? Now, please, you must listen. Something very large and aggressive was lurking out there on the track. I
DOCTOR: don't suppose you know anything about it?
TULUNG: Strangers.
DOCTOR: Only until we're introduced. I'm the Doctor, this is my friend Nyssa, and as I was saying to your friend here, Mister er
GABORIK: You must leave here. This is private property.
NYSSA: You can't just throw us out to face that thing!
GABORIK: You have no business here.
TULUNG: You have no business yourself, Gaborik, throwing out these people into the night. It is for Mister Brett to decide, is it not?
DOCTOR: Oh, absolutely. Good old Mister Brett.
TULUNG: Fetch him, Gaborik. I'll watch them.
NYSSA: Thank you.
DOCTOR: Yes, thank you, Mister er
TULUNG: My name is Tulung. Are you lost?
DOCTOR: Well, I wouldn't say that, exactly.
NYSSA: We know this is Alaska.
TULUNG: Well, welcome to Kyusk.
DOCTOR: I'm sure Mister Brett will be absolutely delighted to see us, but we may find some rather less well-mannered guests dropping by for dinner if whatever's out there is still following us. We need to er. What a terribly lavish reception area. Not very homely though, is it. More like a museum foyer than an entrance hall. No coat stand.
NYSSA: Doctor.
DOCTOR: Nyssa, what's wrong?
NYSSA: I'm not sure. My head, it's tingling.
TULUNG: Please, sit down here. You've been running?
DOCTOR: Yes.
TULUNG: Perhaps the exertion and the change of temperature.
DOCTOR: Well, Nyssa?
NYSSA: I'm fine, really. Please, Doctor, we must find out what that thing was.
DOCTOR: Yes, you're quite right. So, Mister Tulung, this is an impressive building. Do you have equally impressive floodlights for the grounds?
TULUNG: I'll switch them on.
DOCTOR: Splendid. If one of those creatures has followed us, at least we should be able to see what we're up against.
NYSSA: Be careful, Doctor. The readings are clearer here. Look.
DOCTOR: Interesting. Whatever it is, we must be right on top of it. Ah, lead on, Mister Tulung.
DOCTOR: No, not a sign. Perhaps they don't like the light.
TULUNG: Perhaps. And you've seen nothing like these animals before?
DOCTOR: No, I don't believe I have.
TULUNG: I shall leave the lights on.
DOCTOR: Good idea. In the morning we can hunt for tracks.
TULUNG: In the morning? You mean to stay here?
DOCTOR: Ah. I might prevail upon the good nature of our host, yes.
TULUNG: I see.
DOCTOR: Our transport isn't er, always that reliable, and given our recent experience out there.
NYSSA: Well?
DOCTOR: Nothing.
NYSSA: I can't say I'm not relieved.
DOCTOR: How are you feeling?
NYSSA: Better, thank you.
GABORIK: Mister Brett invites you to the drawing room.
DOCTOR: How very pleasant of him.
GABORIK: Take them there, Tulung. I have business to attend to.
NYSSA: I don't think your friend likes us much.
TULUNG: Gaborik doesn't like anyone, and few care for him in return. He holds little respect for the ways of our people, unless it suits him. But come, we'll be more comfortable in the drawing room.
DOCTOR: Well, this is cosy. Thank you, Tulung. It's a large house. Do you stay here too?
TULUNG: Yes, sometimes. There are many guest rooms in the annex here, but I have lodgings at Evansville a few miles away. I prefer it there.
NYSSA: This room, the furnishings, the whole style of it is so different to the hall downstairs. Still, it doesn't feel much like a home.
TULUNG: It was never intended to be. Home is where the heart is. There's no heart in this place, only shadows. Brett had it built for nothing.
DOCTOR: He likes the area?
TULUNG: It's made him a rich man. He's a millionaire a dozen times over now, thanks to Alaskan oil, but yeah, yeah, the area has a special significance.
DOCTOR: The site itself, there's something unusual about it?
TULUNG: His father died not far from here, same place my own dad died.
NYSSA: I'm so sorry.
DOCTOR: I take it that's Brett senior hanging up above the mantelpiece there.
TULUNG: That's right. This place is far more than just somewhere to stay. It's a monument, a kind of mausoleum if you like, a tribute to Brett's father and his all-consuming passion for the land and its secrets.
DOCTOR: He was an archaeologist?
TULUNG: It was his hobby. He used to joke that he'd dig up Alaska any way he could, but for my father. He was a professional. These lands are rich in fossils buried deep in the permafrost. My father was from Colorado, but he spent much of his life out here. It wasn't easy, especially after he married a Koyukon. We moved about all over the state when I was a kid, always chasing more funding, another dig.
NYSSA: And that's how you and Mister Brett first met?
TULUNG: Yeah. And how my father died. What Brett's father lacked in knowledge and ability, he made up for in cash. He funded the digs, but he made damn sure everyone knew who was calling the shots. That's one trait he passed on to his son.
BRETT: An admirable trait, in my view. Everyone knows so clearly where they stand, don't they, little Tulung.
DOCTOR: How do you do? I'm the Doctor.
BRETT: Shaun Brett. And you, my dear?
NYSSA: My name is Nyssa. Thank you for your hospitality.
BRETT: It's a most delightful pleasure for me to have company. This is such a solitary place. How came you to be here in Koyukuk? You're dressed for a
BRETT: game of cricket, I see.
DOCTOR: Yes, sadly called off. Due to snow, apparently.
BRETT: My assistant says you were pursued out there.
DOCTOR: Something like that. Tell me, do you know this area well?
BRETT: I do.
TULUNG: He's hoarding great chunks of it downstairs.
BRETT: I am cherishing this area, shall we say.
DOCTOR: So you'd notice anything unusual about it?
BRETT: Would you care to be shown around downstairs, Doctor, to experience a little of the landscape?
DOCTOR: I'm sorry?
BRETT: Do join me, please. And you, Miss Nyssa.
DOCTOR: Nyssa?
NYSSA: My head, neck. I'm sorry, I think I'll stay here.
TULUNG: I'll wait with you.
BRETT: Do so, little Tulung. We'll not be long.
NYSSA: (sotto) Doctor, what about the tracker, the energy readings?
DOCTOR: (sotto) That's exactly why I think I should take a look around. (normal) Lead on, Mister Brett.
TULUNG: Little Tulung.
NYSSA: He seems a very cold man.
TULUNG: My mother used to say he carries the chill of the lands with him. It's buried in him, like my father's buried out there.
NYSSA: Tulung, I know what it is to lose a father, to lose so much more than that. What happened?
TULUNG: There's not a lot to tell. I was ten, Brett was twelve. It was 1964.
NYSSA: Thirty years ago. I'm sorry. Please, go on.
TULUNG: (sighs) The dig was only a couple of miles from here. They'd found something. My father was excited, terribly excited. But there was a cave-in, something went wrong, something Brett's father never ever talked about, not to anyone. But he was the only one who walked away from that dig alive.
BRETT: And this is the Stone room.
DOCTOR: Everything's solid rock.
BRETT: Naturally. Floor, walls, ceiling, furniture.
DOCTOR: And all local materials?
BRETT: The raw stuff of the area. What better to convey my father's admiration for the lands he embraced so warmly.
DOCTOR: And what better than these lanterns to illuminate it all by. Terribly atmospheric.
BRETT: Reverent, Doctor.
DOCTOR: I'm sorry. Of course. So, a Timber room, an Earth room.
BRETT: I have a room in progress that will be fashioned purely from ice garnered from the Arctic shores.
DOCTOR: Chilly.
BRETT: All aspects of the lands must be reflected, Doctor, for this to be a truly fitting monument. I use wholly natural resources or nothing at all.
DOCTOR: Hmm. And the Koyukon don't mind you carving up great chunks of their land?
BRETT: There Tulung is of use to me. He helps the Koyukon see I am respectful to their lands.
DOCTOR: And Gaborik?
BRETT: Further local colour. He is a somewhat political appointment, I must
BRETT: confess.
DOCTOR: Useful in convincing the Koyukon that you can all work together.
BRETT: Particularly when I'm paying them all so well for their contributions.
DOCTOR: Ah, the age-old conflict. Tradition and progress.
BRETT: Here, I unite them. Doctor, under one roof. The twin watchwords of my father. He uncovered the past and made it his own.
DOCTOR: But was it his to take?
BRETT: And now, if you'd follow me, I shall show you my greatest achievement.
BRETT: My Sea room.
DOCTOR: Shame it's so cold. You'd always have somewhere to lay your beach towel.
BRETT: Remarkable, isn't it? The house is actually build into the rock face. It forms the far wall there.
DOCTOR: And is the rest of the landscape so genuine?
BRETT: Five hundred thousand gallons of Arctic seawater and an actual stretch of coastline, all transplanted and reconstructed.
DOCTOR: You even have your own virtual tides.
BRETT: Keyed to the movement of our holographic moon. There's even sea life here. Seals, walruses.
DOCTOR: Oh, I'm sure they appreciate it all far more than the real thing. Perhaps that's why we can't see any of them today.
BRETT: You don't approve, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Oh, it's an extraordinary achievement, absolutely. It's only the context I question.
BRETT: I can show you someone who would argue that's precisely the point. It's her vision and skill that has brought my dreams to fruition. Perhaps you'd like to meet her?
BRETT: Doctor, may I present Monica Lewis, a most gifted interior designer. Monica, this is my guest for the evening, Doctor
DOCTOR: How do you do?
MONICA: I do fine, thank you, Doctor. A guest, eh? Can't remember when one of those last came to call.
DOCTOR: I imagine you're a little cut off here.
MONICA: Mind the paint.
DOCTOR: It's a little dangerous piled up there, isn't it?
MONICA: Is your friend from Health and Safety, Mister Brett?
BRETT: The Doctor and his friend upstairs are travellers who ran into trouble.
DOCTOR: We so often do. You're the architect of all this, I take it, Miss Lewis.
MONICA: Amongst other things.
DOCTOR: From England?
MONICA: Right. You too?
DOCTOR: Er, not exactly. You know, I'd say your larder here could use a good clean out, Mister Brett.
BRETT: (laughs) Not at all, Doctor. This is my Bone room.
DOCTOR: Isn't that taking your interest in natural materials a little far?
BRETT: This house simply won't be complete without it.
MONICA: Gruesome, isn't it? Gives me nightmares, to be honest. Still, it's a great opportunity. So little provokes a reaction these days.
DOCTOR: And so little is sacred.
BRETT: Your mentioning the larder has reminded me. It's dinner time, Doctor.
DOCTOR: I seem to have lost my appetite.
BRETT: Oh, come, come, Doctor. I insist you dine with me. You and your friend. You too, of course, Monica. We'll spend a pleasant while together.
MONICA: All right, why not?
BRETT: We'll say eight thirty.
NYSSA: That was very nice, Gaborik. Thank you.
DOCTOR: It certainly looked delicious. I'm sorry I wasn't very hungry.
BRETT: Yes, thank you, Gaborik. Workmanlike as ever.
GABORIK: The flesh of the animal was wrong. The taste is not right.
DOCTOR: Really?
MONICA: Glad I'm vegetarian, then. I wouldn't know sea otter from sushi. Great salad though, Gaborik.
GABORIK: It is what they are doing to the sea to get oil that spoils the taste.
DOCTOR: Is it?
BRETT: That's your parochial paranoia speaking again, Gaborik. I shan't allow you to sit at table again if you insist on being so discourteous to the traditions of my Western guests.
GABORIK: Mister Brett.
NYSSA: Please, you shouldn't. There's really no need to
TULUNG: You all right, Nyssa?
NYSSA: I think so.
BRETT: What do you think, Monica? Will these choice table-leavings benefit our Bone room? Oh, it will be a magnificent sight when finished. A shining white chamber, a cage of vertebrae and skulls, a testament to the ancient animal dead.
NYSSA: (nauseous) Please.
BRETT: So squeamish, my dear?
DOCTOR: She's not been well since we got here. Nyssa, look at me. Hmm, you may have a slight temperature.
MONICA: I could use a little walkabout after all that food. Would you like to come along, Nyssa?
NYSSA: Thank you, I, I think I might.
DOCTOR: Probably just what you need.
BRETT: Now, where were we?
TULUNG: You were trying to provoke Gaborik and myself into arguing yet again against your ghoulish vision. The Koyukon
BRETT: It's so sweet when you try and empathise with Gaborik's views.
MONICA: Something's stirring. Maybe this walk wasn't such a good idea. Come on, let's get some sea air. Well, the next best thing. Might cool this fever down a little.
NYSSA: The sea. Something from the sea.
MONICA: You're not well, are you? Tell you what, you just rest here. I'll go and tell your friend. He's a doctor.
NYSSA: Something from the sea.
TULUNG: You just don't get it, Brett. Animals need to be treated with respect, or they would not give themselves to the hunter.
BRETT: Such tedious superstition.
TULUNG: It's not superstition! It's something that's evolved over thousands of years. The culture, the land, the animals, they can't be separated and packaged up the way you're doing.
BRETT: Listen to your choice of words. Does that sound like a Koyukon to
BRETT: you, Gaborik?
GABORIK: I wouldn't really
BRETT: You're really trying too hard, little Tulung.
TULUNG: I won't let you
DOCTOR: I really to think
MONICA: Doctor! I think you'd better take a look
MONICA: What the hell was that?
DOCTOR: It came from below us.
BRETT: That's the Stone room. Quickly.
MONICA: The whole wall's cracked open. How can that have happened? It's impossible.
BRETT: Well, it evidently has, my dear Monica.
MONICA: I worked on this myself.
BRETT: Am I to blame your handiwork?
MONICA: I wouldn't, if I were you. We'll have to re-render the entire wall. Damn. How deep is it?
DOCTOR: Wait, wait, wait. Let me take a look.
MONICA: What?
DOCTOR: Yes, something's caused that rock to break open.
MONICA: Hold on. I, I can see something inside this split.
DOCTOR: Careful. Yes, you're right. Where's Nyssa?
MONICA: Oh, she wasn't up to walking far. I left her resting in the Sea room.
DOCTOR: I'd better fetch her. Touch nothing, any of you, until we're back. Nothing.
BRETT: Cheek of the man.
MONICA: We'd better get a light in here. There's definitely something in the rock.
BRETT: Let me see. Gaborik, fetch a stronger light, man.
TULUNG: The Doctor said we should leave it.
GABORIK: It is bad, I sense it.
MONICA: Looks to be some kind of fossil.
DOCTOR: Nyssa? Nyssa, are you all right? The door seems to be stuck.
NYSSA: From the sea. It's so dark in here, so cold.
DOCTOR: [OC]: Nyssa! Nyssa, if you can hear me, come to the door..
NYSSA: Doctor, they're coming for me!
DOCTOR: [OC]: What's happening, Nyssa?
NYSSA: Creatures, born and reborn. They're all around me. They want to kill, want to kill us all!
DOCTOR: [OC]: Nyssa!

elements.text: [Part Two]
Banging on Sea room door.
What is happening?
Gaborik, help me, man. There's something wedged up against the door. Nyssa's trapped inside.
[OC]: Doctor!
What are they, Nyssa?
[OC]: Too dark.
Right, together. One, two
Door pushed.
Quickly, come on, again. It's giving.
[OC]: One of them's blocking the door.
Door creaks open a little.
My leg!
Watch out. Nyssa, quickly, squeeze through.
Oh, Doctor.
The door, Gaborik. Help me.
Door closes.
Nyssa?
I'm all right now. They were the same as the creatures that attacked us outside.
Yes. Gaborik, what sea life has Brett been keeping in there?
(in pain) Native animals. Walrus, sea otter, fur seal.
And there's no way in or out other than this door?
That is right.
But then that's it. I saw them, when the light spilled in as you opened the door.
Yes?
They're not natural. Each creature was composed of several living things. I saw eyes all over them, giant teeth, blubbery skin.
The energy readings here, enough to fuse flesh?
Doctor, they're in such pain. I could feel it.
And you felt they were hostile?
Yes.
She knows the creatures. She has communed with Sedna.
Sedna?

The sea-spirit of my people from the distant time. The creatures of the sea were formed of her flesh, grown from the severed joints of her fingers. She was drowned, betrayed by her own father. She sank to the bottom of the sea, and she is there still, ruling over Adlivum.
Adlivum?
The land of the dead.
Yes, well, it's a lovely story, but it doesn't really explain how vivisection can occur spontaneously in freezing cold water.
It is true, Doctor. It is revenge for the bodies of the animals the woman Lewis uses as decoration. The spirits of these animals know what has become of them. Bad luck will follow, even death.
What were you doing here, anyway?
Brett wanted me to fetch some lights to see inside the rock. No good will come of this.
Perhaps. We'd better go and see.
Tulung knows the culture. The land, the people are one. Perhaps you will believe the same story from a respectable American?
That's a tail bone protruding, I'm sure of it. If we pull a little more of this rock away
No. Don't touch it.
You're very proprietorial, Doctor, considering this is my house.
Aren't I. Listen to me, Brett. Something's happening here that's placing us all in danger, and Nyssa was almost killed in your Sea room.
What? Preposterous.
It's true.
What happened, Gaborik?
She saw one of Sedna's familiars.
I saw something unnatural.
Our ancient spirits are stirring.
Nyssa, come outside. I'll fetch you a drink to calm yourself and you can tell me.
Thank you, Tulung. Now, Gaborik's found us a torch that works. Let me have a look at this fissure.
Torch clicks on, something swishes.
(gasps) Oh, my God! Oh, my God, what is that thing?
That's no fossil. It's alive, it's moving.
I think it's trying to pull itself out. Everyone back.
Swish, swish.
If it holds its tail still for long enough, I can get a sample with this.
What is that?
A laser scalpel. Every home should have one. Or will have one. Come on, now, calm down for a moment. There!
Roar of pain, rocks fall.
What was that?
You must have hurt it! It felt that.
Ow. So did I. It's burning hot.
Doctor, what is it?
Another candidate for our energy field readings.
This has to be some kind of joke. Give it here. But it's just bone, isn't it? How can it be moving about?
I don't know, but I think we'd better find out. It seems to be held pretty tight in there, whatever it is.
Could the heat from its tail have caused that fissure in the rock?
Together with some other force.
I, I'm locking the door.
Very sensible. I'll just take a couple of samples of the rock while we're about it.
Door closed and locked. Occasional sound of tail swishing.
Mister Brett, I must speak with you.
Can't it wait?
No, I must speak to you now.
Well, tell me on the way to the Sea room. I want to witness the Doctor's new creatures for myself.
Be very careful.
Of course.
Footsteps recede.
Gaborik's really rattled. Believes it's vengeance from the distant time.
And you?
No. No, it can't be. There has to be another explanation, doesn't there?
An open mind. Excellent. I think we're in for a few surprises. Now, Nyssa, this could be right up your street.
What?
Well, you're the bioelectronics expert.
Are you?
You think that might have some bearing on that bone creature?
Well, it might explain how ossified calcium can become an animated creature. Some kind of bioelectric force.
Occurring naturally?
I don't know. I just don't know.
It could explain the emissions we picked up.
But could it explain the cell hybridisation in the creatures in the Sea room?
If that creature in the stone was regenerating itself in some way, that could have been a by-product of the process.
But why?
I'm glad you two know what you're talking about.
Too many questions, it seems. Where can we find analysing equipment in the Arctic Circle in the middle of the night?
The Tardis?
You know the journey. It's quite a way and we'd have to leave the road for a good deal of it. We don't know how many hybrids may be out there or understand how this happened to them.
I have some equipment in portakabins a mile or so from here.
Really? What sort of equipment?

Er, a spectroscope, I think. A lot of the stuff there's just for show. You know, some Koyukon relics and remains were dug up when the Earth room was being made, and we set up a little camp there to study them.
No doubt your fathers would have approved.
Well, to be honest, we didn't do much with them, Miss Lewis. It was good PR to make a show of studying the relics and then returning them to the community.
Well, we must be a little more thorough with this. We'd better leave at once.
Is that wise?
I take it you've got transport, Tulung?
Yeah, a four by four right outside.
Those creatures aren't fast. In a car or a cabin we should be safe enough.
Footsteps approach.
Notice.
I will not stay.
I can't explain this yet, but surely, man, you're no savage. You can see it's nothing from your superstitions.
The Raven Father is angry. Denying his truth will not save you from his judgement. An evil is stirring, and I, I helped it to happen.
Oh, have it your own way, you witless savage. Go on. Go on, get out of here.
Gentlemen, perhaps we should calm ourselves, hmm?
It's not safe to go outside alone. The creature that hunted us will still be out there.
I will not stay here.
We're taking the four by four to the portakabins down near the Utuskgappa.
Oh, are you?
Perhaps you could come?
You wish to use science. Science will not explain this.
I wish somebody would.
You strangers, you brought bad luck.
I hardly think
You brought these creatures with you.
That's not true!
They're a little large to fit into our pockets, or hadn't you noticed.
The creature was in the rock, Gaborik. How could they
I will listen to no more of this. I am taking my belongings from
this place.
Footsteps recede.
Great. Pretend nothing's happening, that'll help.
He's scared.
He's not the only one.
I, I can't
Are you all right?
Brett, you look unwell.
Let me see. Ah, much the same as you were, Nyssa. A slight fever.
I'm much better now.
I'm sure you'll be all right too, Mister Brett. You should rest. Tulung?
I'll take him upstairs.
Footsteps recede.
When I felt unwell, I felt, I felt like I was being called to.
Who by? What were they saying?
I don't know. It wasn't words. I just knew. Could that creature have affected us somehow?
A side-effect of that energy force, perhaps, or an intended influence?
Keep on like this and I'm going to join Gaborik, hiding under the bed.
We must know more about that thing rattling about in there. If I could just place the genus.
Doctor, why don't I go with Tulung to see what tests I can run at the camp there, while you stay and learn more about whatever that creature is.
You're sure?
Yes.
Miss Lewis?
Monica.
Will you go with her?
I don't think so. I think staying here's the lesser of two evils on this occasion. Wish it wasn't so dark at night here. No street lamps, no city lights in the distance.
No, I'm afraid we're rather on our own. Still might as well make the best of it. Cup of tea would be an excellent start.
Well, you'll find a kettle and tea bags in the room third on your left down there. Only UHT milk, I'm afraid.
Ah.
I like mine strong, with sugar.
Nothing for me, thank you, Doctor.
Right then.
More fossil tail swishing in the distance.
Just doesn't stop, does it, even without an audience.
I do hope Nyssa and Tulung get in touch soon.
I love this room. It's so soothing. All this earth.
Mmm.
A garden in a room. Bare nature captured on the cusp of fertility.
Yes, it's all very clever.
Those mosses weren't even there when we first lay in the earth, or those grasses.
Nature finds a way, usually. Back in the Bone room you mentioned you'd been having nightmares.
What? Oh, yeah.
You've had them often?
Recently, yeah.
Well, what are they like?
Oh, it's all rubbish, just kid's stuff. You know, trapped in a room, Knowing there's something outside, something closing in. Always wake up before I find out what.
Hmm. That's quite possibly your own mind's slant on the feeling that's affecting Brett and Nyssa. Some kind of instinctive foreboding. Very interesting.
Will I get sick? I was going to be insufferably smug for a moment. I thought it was something they ate.
Oh dear. The meat. Gaborik said the taste was wrong. If the flesh had been irradiated with the creature's energies, ingesting it could possibly help the effect take hold on the conscious mind.
Talk about food poisoning. How much did Tulung have of it?
I don't know. But the feelings would have been growing stronger with the creature's strength regardless.
That's why Nyssa had a funny turn.
Yes. Well, if Tulung does start to suffer, at least he'll be in good hands.
I put the nightmares down to stress, overwork, three years of living in a freezer.
Brett works you hard?

I work me hard. He's a bit twisted, but Brett's never bothered me. And with a commission this size, I mean, I know it's a bit unsound, all this tearing up the environment stuff, but that's down to him, isn't it?
Hmm, isn't it.
I mean, the artistic freedom he's given me, the money.
Your candour does you credit.

I won't need credit when I go back home, I'm telling you. And with this in my portfolio. It's all on such a grand scale. It was a dream job when I got it. Fairy tale stuff. Hmm. Fairy tales have happy endings, right?
Speaking of tails, what's really driven Brett to carry his obsession so far?
According to Tulung, a dig that went horribly wrong. Subsidence. The supports weren't strong enough and the roof fell in. The people inside were entombed.
Including Tulung's father.

And Brett's dad was the only one who got out. There was no actual witnesses on the dig site. Brett makes out his dad was running around trying to get help to free all those caught inside, but it was all too late. A tragic accident, that's what the inquest concluded. Others said Brett senior ran off like a scalded cat, or flew off, anyway.
Flew off? He left the site in a two man plane, a yellow one.
I wasn't there.
And all that smoke we saw on the scanner from a fall-in, and still lingering by the time he was airborne.
Anyway, some of the bodies were never found.
Was Tulung's father among the missing?

Mmm, washed away to sea, they said. Nothing was ever proved, but the rumours got about. Did Brett's father a lot of damage, professional and personal. He never really recovered. Died a year or so later. Brett idolised him.
Hence the obsession. Hence the monument. Hence your involvement.
Funny how things turn out, isn't it?
Wind, diesel engine.
Why do you stay with Brett, Tulung, after all that happened?
It's because of the past. All along it's been his word against mine as to what happened. My father was a coward, trembling as the rocks fell. His father, the brave leader, trying to save everyone.
So you wait together in case one day you can prove the other wrong once and for all.
You know, yeah, I actually think he blames my father for getting killed and sending his father mad.
And you blame his father in turn.
Shouldn't I?
You both laid that blame first as children.
Nothing's changed, don't you see? My spirit's bound to Brett's and he knows it. I can't move on until I know for sure that I was right.
Tulung, if I told you that a plane did fly from the site, would it help you to
How do you know?
The plane was yellow. A number seven was painted on its side. The sky was clear that day.
You did see it. But how?
I can't explain how I know, but you must trust me.
Nyssa, Nyssa, I can't tell you what this means.
Look out!
Roar, crash! Vehicle slithers to a halt in the snow.
Mighty Father protect us!
That was one of them!
Did we kill it?
I don't know.
I never meant to.
Tulung, we must keep going.
The engine won't restart.
Gaborik was right. The spirits are angry.
No! Keep trying.
Oh, it's no good.
A creature attacks the vehicle.
And another one!
Door opens.
(scared) No. No, Father, come back. Dad!
You are arrogant, Brett. It is the Raven Father you should call to, not your own dead. Only he can quell these forces we have brought upon ourselves.
Father, don't leave! They're here.
I am leaving. I shall not be returning here.
No. Oh, such pain. I can't think, can't even see. Frozen.
Door closes.
Come on, Nyssa. You know, this Earth room of yours would benefit from garden furniture of some kind. Make it much more pleasant.
Doctor, is it my imagination, or is that thing getting louder?
Are there separate walls dividing each room?
No. The construction fabrics are so strong any way.
So they back directly onto each other?
Yeah. Stone room to Earth room, Timber room to Bone room. We use thermal sheets to separate them. It helps keep each room's ambient temperature
How thick are they?
Not very. What are you saying?
We were wrong. It wasn't trying to pull itself out at all.
Crash! Monica cries out.
It was trying to burrow its way through to here.
Stomping of bony feet.
Look at it.
It's blocking the door.
It's got no eyes, only sockets. How can it see us?
Hold on.
Slow footsteps. A roar then stomping.
I don't know how it can see us, but it can. Or it senses us, anyway.
Look, with its head cocked like that, it's as if it's listening to us.
It's sizing us up. It won't have seen anything like us before.
Those teeth, there must be hundreds of them.
Yes, it's a saurischian theropod.
Sorry?
A lizard-hipped carnivore, moving on its hind legs.
Obviously.
Which means it's probably fast. And probably quite hungry.
Gunshots and engine failing to turn over. Creatures approaching.
It's no good.
We must do it.
Then the engine catches, and they get wheel spin as they drive off.
Come on, quickly.
There's one in front.
We've got to get away.
Thud.
We killed it.
We didn't have any choice.
You speak with such certainty.
I only know
Gaborik said you'd communed with Sedna, the Sea Spirit.
No, no, it's more complicated than that.
Speak to her again, Nyssa. You can see into the past, search out truths. Reach out to her now. Appease her.
I can't! All we can do is get this bone tested, find out all we can from it and get back to the Doctor before it's too late.
Bone dinosaur making plaintive noises.
So what do we do?
Try and crawl through the hole it's made to the other room, slowly as you can, then double back and open the door.
The dinosaur stomps.
Oh God, I think I'm going to be sick.
The door opens.
No, Gaborik, get back.
The dinosaur turns.
Raven Father!
Stomping.
No!
We've got to get that thing off him.
No!
Monica, get back.
But we can't
Look.
Crackling sound.
Oh, my God.
The energy field that thing gives off, it's strong enough to peel flesh from bone at close range.
But how, why?
So it can eat faster. It's developed a more efficient way of removing meat than simply chewing.
And yet the way that it tore at his clothes before.
Fussy eater? I don't know. Now quickly, up the stairs before it decides it's still hungry. Come on. Go!
Howling wind. Vehicle arrives, engine is turned off. Doors open and close.
This is it.
Quickly, we must get inside.
Walk on snow, open door.
Where are the lights?
Door closed.
Here. Everything's run from a generator below us.
Oh, I'd hoped for more to work with than this equipment. Quite primitive, but I should be able to get some results.
Primitive? This technology's state of the art, for all the good technology can do us now.
The spiritual and the rational, Tulung, remember? Each must lead the other. I'd better get to work.
Distant roars.
What's it waiting down there for? Why doesn't it come after us?
Looks a little unsteady on its feet, doesn't it. Spot of indigestion at it's first human, perhaps.
Don't use words like first.
The dinosaur runs off.
And there it goes. This must be a very unsettling world to find itself in.
Oh, poor little thing.
You must find Brett, see how he is. We should all stay together.
So we can present a three course banquet to it. Perhaps we should all just take our clothes off while we're at it, save it a job.
Er, I don't think that'll be necessary. We're not ready to become a dinosaur dinner just yet, are we?
Neither was poor Gaborik, and look at him. Well, look what happened to him.
Just fetch Brett, would you?
All right.
Footsteps recede.
Now come on, Doctor. Think.
Tell me more truths, Nyssa. What really happened to my father?
I don't know, Tulung, I swear. I can only tell you what I saw.
Beeps
Goodness.
What is it?
The Doctor told us, told me, that the dinosaurs died out sixty five
million years ago.
So?
I estimate this fragment to be over two hundred and sixty million years old.
And yet that thing is still alive?
We have to find out how that can be.
With this primitive equipment?
With a small amount of ion bonding, I may be able to enhance it.
Brett. Brett, wake up.
Yes.
You have to wake up.
Why? Why should I?
Because we're in trouble, and because I think the Doctor's the only person who might be able to get us out of it.
Everything in the Sea room, all that cold, slippery life. Like the past, like everything I've known, all ruined, changed, dead.
There's no time for this.
(gasps) Can't you feel it? Ancient death stalking us like animals. Can't you feel it?
Yes, I can feel it. I've bloody well seen it. It killed Gaborik, ate him alive. Now are you coming?
Dead? Gaborik's dead?
I think I can hear something outside.
Oh, no. Tulung.
Shh. There's something out there, I'm telling you.
We must phone the Doctor.
How can he help us?
I need to tell him what I've discovered.
Telephone ringing.
Nyssa! (walking) This does lead me into the lion's den, rather. If this is a wrong number, I shall not be happy.
Phone ringing here, too.
That must be the Doctor's friend. Get off me!
Something else. Something else stirring down there.
Telephone answered.
Nyssa?
[OC]: Doctor.
Are you all right? You're safe? Tulung's not sick?
[OC]: No, no, we're both fine, for now. We ran into more of those hybrid creatures, and now Tulung thinks he can hear something outside.
For the last time, Brett, let me go.
Cracking sound in distance.
Oh, sweet Jesus, not again.
Big noise.
Oh, no. The Stone room again.
[OC]: Doctor? Are you there?
Yes, Nyssa. Quickly, what have you found?
[OC]: It's ancient. I estimate those rock samples to be two hundred and sixty million years old.
What? That's thirty million years before the first dinosaurs. About the time, yes, might fit. Er, go on.
[OC]: You were right. It carries a bioelectric field inside itself. Quite a powerful one from the residue left in this sample. That must be how it's able to move.
Yes, go on. Anything else?
[OC]: I think the energy field must be generated by the creature's brain. I can't say whether it will do so intentionally or otherwise.
It's visual appearance is terrifying enough, but if it developed the ability to affect its prey mentally, yes, an evolutionary breakthrough.
Roars and approaching stomping.
Oh dear.
[OC]: What is it?
The skeletal creature, it's broken free, and we can't stop it.
[OC]: What?
And now it's moving towards me.
[OC]: What? How close is it?
Er, twelve metres or so, but it's, it's, it's changed. It looks bigger than before.
[OC]: Bigger? Doctor, you must get out of there.
And the skeleton looks different. It's moving more upright. The tail is less pronounced.
[OC]: Has it seen you?
Oh yes.
[OC]: But how fast is it?
Very.
[OC]: Doctor, you have to get out
Nyssa, are you there? What's happened? Nyssa!
Close growling.
Ah. Dinnertime so soon.
Roar!
